Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a Solid State NMR Instrument at Rutgers University for Research and Teaching Activities in New Jersey Area
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities: Departmental Multi-User Instrumentation program (CRIF:MU), Professors Eric L. Garfunkel and colleagues Tewodros Asefa, Martha Greenblatt, Frank Jordan and Bozena Michniak from the Department of Chemistry at Rutgers University New Brunswick will acquire a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer for the study of solids. The instrument will be used to support research activities such as: 1) sample composition of nanoporous materials and inorganic catalysts; 2) polymers used for drug delivery applications; 3) inorganic catalysts capable of effecting fundamental transformations to yield fuels and chemicals; 4) thermoelectric materials useful for energy transformation; 5) mesoporous metal oxide, semiconductor and polymer gel electrolytes for energy applications; and 6) biopolymers and biomolecules useful for treatment of diseases and disease diagnostics.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solids and in solution. Because this particular instrument will analyze substances in the solid state it will provide valuable structural information on a variety on insoluble materials. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials and biochemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research in the fields of chemistry, materials science, biochemistry, polymers, and engineered materials has been driving technology and science by creating novel materials and compounds with unique and new physical, magnetic, and chemical properties. These materials and compounds enable the development of technologically important devices and systems in nanoelectronics, catalysis, nanomedicine, and sensors. Research in these areas requires intensive characterization of the composition and structures of these systems. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most important characterization tools for new materials. It not only enables researchers to probe composition and structure but also provides a broad range of structure-property-function relationships. The NMR spectrometer (400- MHz solid-state NMR (ssNMR) spectrometer) we have acquired, thanks to the kind support of NSF, was installed in our Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology at Rutgers at New Brunswick in spring 2012 and has since been up and running well. The instrument is being managed by our NMR spectroscopist, Dr. Nagarajan Murali. Dr. Murali also oversees its daily uses, helps with the proper training of students and consultation of the experiments that our PIs’ and students do, and does trouble-shooting of the instrument, as necessary. Since its installation, the instrument has been intensively used by many students and users around Rutgers. The number of users is expected to increase in the next few years as many more new research groups are currently gearing up and planning to do solid state NMR experiments. Access to ssNMR has not only been crucial for studies currently being conducted by many researchers at Rutgers and around New Jersey, but also has energized many new interdisciplinary studies among researchers who are working on biomaterials, polymers, nanocatalysts, batteries, fuel cells, and nanomaterials for renewable energy.

The ssNMR instrument has also complemented the extensive array of existing solution-phase NMR instruments at Rutgers and help many researchers perform state-of-the-art characterization of various types of new solid–phase materials, including solid state catalysts that are useful for the production of various synthetic materials, pharmaceuticals and renewable energy sources. The instrument has also helped many researchers to do fundamental studies in elucidation of structure and property of various novel materials, polymers, and biomolecules that are relevant for nanomedicine, polymer drug delivery, nanotechnology, catalysis, energy conversion and storage, and environmental remediation.

The instrument has also made many researchers around Rutgers no longer to send samples to other institutions for characterization by solid state NMR spectroscopy.  In the past, this used to cause delays, higher costs, and increased time to publication. It used also affect the proper training of research students, who require ssNMR for their research.
